moves.1. e4: This is a mini tournament game against a player about 200 pnts above myself,  Please feel free to make any constructive comments on improvements that could be made.  e4 , my most common opening.
moves.2. e5: I decide to push my pawn to attack his knight rather than defend the pawn.
moves.2... Nd5 3. d4: d4, opening up my queens bishop and protecting the advanced pawn.
moves.3... e6: I like this position, my e5 is already cramping the fox's style and I have a open game.
moves.4. c4: normally I would go Nf3 here but I decided to keep that black horse on the run and try to get more control of the centre.
moves.4... Nb6 5. Nc3: time to start giving my brave pawns some support.
moves.5... Bb4: I thought the fox would reply with that move but it does leave g2 very weak. Both his kingside knight and bishop have abandoned there sides. I need to exploit this.
moves.6. Qg4: So I decide to attack g7 knowing if he castle's then I can bring my bishop to h6.
moves.6... h6: maybe Bf3 might have been better, I know its a backward'sstep in development but it protects the pawn.  Or g6 maybe.
moves.8... Qe7: Only one possible move for black to stop checkmate.
moves.9. Nf3: I pondered for a while. I was 2 up and queen and bishop in a good place . I did contemplate exchanging queens here( 9.Qf6, Qxf6.10. exf6) He could of course wait until I exchanged and simply moved Rg8 so I decided against that.  I wanted more support out and my king tucked away too so I moved Nf3.
moves.9... Nc6: Black starts to develop now there is a sort of impasse on the king side.
moves.10. Bd3: It was still bugging me if I should move Qf6?  Instead decide on bringing my other bishop into play.
moves.10... d5: I thought this was a good move. , attacking c4 but at the same time opening d7 for his knight to move into to protect his rook and cover f3.
Was this a mistake?  That was a good pawn on e5.
moves.11... cxd6 12. O-O: castling, freeing up my knight on c3.
moves.12... Bxc3: Black takes action now that the knight is not pinned.  He decides to exchange and in the process double my pawns up.
moves.13. bxc3 Nd7: Black makes that protecting move. His King does look cramped.
moves.14. Bg5: Bg5??  should I have gone d5? attacking his knight and pawn. Ready for one of my rooks to slide to e1 attacking his queen.
moves.14... f6: I have to exchange now. I did think of moving Bg3+
moves.15. Qxe7+ Kxe7: The fox now has a good wall of pawns in front of his king, I'm still 2 up but i've lost alot of my advantage.
moves.16. Bh4 b6 17. Rfe1: Here I was pinning 2 of his pawns, e6 and f6. Could I exploit this?
moves.17... Bb7: Black unites his rooks and brings his bishop on the long diagonal. Things are starting to look better for black.
moves.19... Nxe5 20. Rad1: I needed to bring my other rook into the game. To protect my bishop and pawn.
moves.20... Rac8 21. dxe6: my worry here was that I was opening the h1-a8 line for his bishop and with the g and h file wide open the fox could mount  a serious attack. Still I decided to break into his wall of pawns. In the process if he went Kxe6 his knight would be pinned.
moves.22... Rfh8: and he in  turn attacks my bishop.
moves.23. Bg3 Ba6 24. fxe5 fxe5: Slowly but surely the kings defenses are vanishing.
moves.25. Re4: c4 was in danger ! so I protected it with my rook. In preparation for doubling them on the e file.
moves.25... Rcg8: Black swithes his play to the open files.
moves.26. a4: I wanted to advance c4 to attack d6 to take e5 protection away but first I needed b6 out of the way .
moves.26... Bb7: Black attacks my rook but also a worry to me was g2. Bishop and a potetial rook attack.
moves.27. Re2: I had to withdraw and protect g2 at the same time.
moves.27... Bc6: Attacking my a pawn  and tring to create a passed pawn
moves.28... bxa5: He now has a fox on the run but I can now look at his kings defenses.
moves.29. c5 Rxg3: Black decides to take the presure off of e5 by sacrificing his rook .
moves.30. hxg3: However all my pawns are now doubled now and black has took the sting out of my attack. Still 5 up.
moves.33. Rf2: I need to try to get around the back some how. I needed to be careful which rook I moved. Move Rf1 and his bishop was lurking ...Bb5 winning one of my rooks.
moves.34. g4: Looking to check him on f5.
moves.34... Bd7: Black defends f5 and attacks g4. By moving the bishop there though he does take a defender awy from d5.
moves.35. c4: So I decide against advancing g4 and opt for c4 instead attacking d5. I know I will be a pawn down in the exchange but I want that king out from behind those pesky pawns.
moves.35... Bxg4 36. cxd5 Kxd5 37. Bxe4+: Black king is now in the open. My dilema here was do I take e4 with my rook or bishop, I went with the latter. A wrong choice I feel now. 37. Rxe4 would have been better attacking both a4 and g4.
moves.37... Kxc5: He was 3 pawns to 2 up in that exchange. It should have been better for me.
moves.38. Rb1: still 4 up. So not too bad.  I did not want that fox been aided by his king so blocked that route off.
moves.39. Ra2: That fox is now keeping busy 2 rooks. Not good for me.
moves.39... Re8: Black makes his move while my rooks are stuck.
moves.40. Rxa3: A risk.  I would not have done this if I was not 4 up but my thoughts were, better having 2 mobile rooks and no foxes to worry about in exchange for my bishop. Was this a right play?
moves.40... Rxe4 41. Rxa7: My advantage is dwindling a little.
moves.41... Kc6 42. Rg7: Im thinking long and hard if I should exchange my rook for his bishop. Maybe not a good exchange.
Stopping blacks king or bishop attacking my rook and keeping his king away from mine.
moves.47... Ke5 48. g3: Gives my king some breathing space.
moves.50. Kh2: My only move. An exchange would have meant a draw.
moves.51. Rf6f8: My idea here is to try and pin his bishop with Re8.
moves.51... Ra1 52. Re8 Ra6: Blacksaw the attack. I was planning Re2 next and he would have lost his bishop but now he has it protected.
moves.53. g4: So I decide to advance my pawn knowing that my Rook on the f file stops the king attacking it.
moves.53... Kd6 54. g5: I have to move the pawn as he has unpinned his bishop.
moves.54... Kd7 55. Ref8: I reunite my rooks. Boy this is tough and taking some time to work out.  Cat and mouse at the moment.
moves.56. Rf8f4: I block the potential black rook move of Rg4 or Rh4+ and offer my rook up for exchange.
moves.56... Ra3: Of course black does not want the exchange and trys another way through threatening Rh3+
moves.59... Ra3+: Now I need to be careful!!!  Kh4 would result in disaster!  Kh4?? Rh3#!  My own pawn blocking the kings escape.
moves.61... Ra3 62. g6: I decide to advance my pawn ahead of blocking again.
moves.64... Bd5+ 65. Kg3: again moving King to g1 would have resulted in a lost game.
moves.65... Rh1: Black looks to put his rook on g1 attacking King and pawn.
moves.66. Rf6f7+: I thought about this one for a while. I may loose a rook but I would queen my pawn if he took it.  Plus If he did not go for it I would have my rook on the 7th rank.
moves.66... Ke8: I thought this was a poor move .  His king is now trapped on the back rank.
moves.67. Rh7: If he exchanges , I Queen.  I spot a checkmate at last. Moving my f Rook to  to b2.  Will the fox see it.
moves.68. Kh4: I moved in here  rather than to the middle of the board to stop being chased about.
moves.69... Bg8: Maybe R d6 would have prolonged it.
moves.70. Rb8#: The end at last.  I nearly blew it a couple of times. Up to date my biggest scalp. A very nice game to play.
